items.title: Say hi to ECMAScript 2024
items.content:
#â€‹694 â€” June 27, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

A Look at JavaScript's New Set Methods â€” Finding the intersection, union, and difference between sets, among other set-related tasks, is now a piece ofÂ cake. Available in Node 22+, Chrome/Edge 122+, Firefox 127+, Safari 17+, and now considered a 'baseline' feature.

Brian Smith (MDN)

Ecma International Approves ECMAScript 2024: Whatâ€™s New? â€” This week, the Ecma General Assembly approved the latest ECMAScript / JavaScript language spec, officially making it a standard. As with ECMAScript 2023, itâ€™s a small step forward, but Dr. Axel looks at whatâ€™sÂ new.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Create Consistent UIs with Storybook â€” Join Steve Kinney for this extensive video course on building scalable, reusable component libraries and design systems with Storybook. Covers set up, styling, documentation, testing,Â andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Announcing TypeScript 5.5 â€” One of the most significant TypeScript releases in terms of features in a long time. Thereâ€™s support for the new Set methods (mentioned above), regex syntax checking, isolated declarations, inferred type predicates, and more. A bumper packed releaseÂ post.

Microsoft

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“Š Socket's Sarah Gooding has put together a good, easily-skimmed roundup of the State of JS 2023 survey results.

  • ğŸ§Š Someone's created an ASCII 3D renderer in JavaScript. Why? Why not! There's a live demo here.

RELEASES:

  • Playwright 1.45.0 â€“ Microsoft's browser/Web automation library now has a clock API for manipulating time within tests to verify time-relatedÂ behavior.

  • Bun v1.1.16 â€“ The fast JavaScript runtime andÂ toolkit.

  • Astro 4.11, Electron 31.1, PouchDB 9.0, Node.js v20.15.0 (LTS)

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

ğŸ‘‘Â Recreating the Queens Game in Vue â€” Queens is a puzzle game that combines elements of Minesweeper, chess, andÂ Sudoku.

Fotis Adamakis

Understanding React Compiler â€” The new, experimental tool from the React team automates your performance tuning by rewriting your code â€”Â but should you use it, and how does it work under the hood? Tony takes aÂ look.

Tony Alicea

Local-First Development Will Be Unlocked by Sync Engines â€” Sync engines are behind the amazing UX of apps like Linear and Figma. PowerSync is a plug-in sync engine for webÂ apps.

PowerSync sponsor

Uniting Web and Native Apps with 4 Lesser-Known JavaScript APIs â€” Looks at some 'under-the-radar' web features, such as the Screen Orientation API and Contact Picker API, and how they can be used to create user friendlyÂ PWAs.

Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez

Exploring Randomness in JavaScript â€” Specifically, Math.random() versus Crypto.getRandomValues().

Ben Nadel

Drawing the Auth Owl at Userfront | Transformational Auth & Identity â€” Read the story behind Userfront. Including the vision behind the company and what auth should (and shouldn't)Â have.

Userfront sponsor

ğŸ“„ Slack's AI-Powered Conversion from Enzyme to React Testing Library â€“ If the robots are taking jobs, at least they're the jobs that we often don't want to do.. Sergii Gorbachov (Slack)

ğŸ“„ How to Mock a Child Component When Writing Angular Tests Casey Falkowski

ğŸ“„ Morphing Arbitrary Paths in SVG Alexandru-Gabriel IcÄƒ

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Node-RED 4.0 Released â€” Node-RED is a popular â€˜low codeâ€™ event-driven app development environment that uses Node.js behind the scenes. v4.0 requires Node 18 or up, improves its â€˜multiplayerâ€™ support (when multiple users are working on the same system), faster deploys, and other all-roundÂ improvements.

OpenJS Foundation

React-Admin v5 â€” A MIT-licensed framework for building React apps on top of REST or GraphQL APIs. You get some added structure and numerous building blocks out of the box. GitHubÂ repo.

FranÃ§ois Zaninotto

Deploy Your SSR Apps on AWS, Fast â€” Deploy any frontend framework quickly with AWS Amplify hosting. Scale to millions? âœ… Branch deployment? âœ… PR previews?Â âœ…

AWS Amplify sponsor

wavesurfer.js: Audio Waveform Player Library â€” Get responsive and customizable waveforms that provide a visual impression of audio. There are plugins for working with timelines, recording, rendering spectrograms, and more. Many examplesÂ here.

katspaugh

PixelMatch 6.0: A Fast Pixel-Level Image Comparison Library â€” Give it two images, itâ€™ll highlight the differences. Now distributed as a ESÂ module.

Mapbox

ğŸ“„Â PDFSlick: View and Interact with PDFs â€” An interesting PDF viewer for React, Solid, Svelte and other JavaScript apps. Built on top of PDF.js, it uses Zustand to provide a reactive store for loaded documents. LiveÂ demos.

Vancho Stojkov

  • Ky 1.4 â€“ Simple HTTP client based upon Fetch for browsers, NodeÂ &Â Deno.

  • React Awesome Query Builder 6.6 â€“ Logical query builder control.Â (Demo.)

  • Matter.js 0.20 â€“ A 2D rigid body physics engine.

  • ka-table 11.0 â€“ Lightweight React table component.Â (Demos.)

  • OverlayScrollbars 2.9 â€“ JS custom scrollbarÂ plugin.

  • Wouter 3.3 â€“ Minimalist router for React &Â Preact.

ğŸ“„ Morphing Arbitrary Paths in SVG  Alexandru-Gabriel IcÄƒ

Node-RED 4.0 Released â€” Node-RED is a popular â€˜low codeâ€™ event-driven app development environment that uses Node.js behind the scenes. v4.0 requires Node 18 or up, improves its â€˜multiplayerâ€™ support (when multiple users are working on the same system), faster deploys, and other all-roundÂ improvements.

items.title: The results are in
items.content:
#â€‹693 â€” June 20, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The Results of the State of JavaScript 2023 Survey â€” It feels odd including something about 2023 in June 2024, but the results of the major annual JavaScript developer survey are now out. Itâ€™s interesting to see what features JS devs do and donâ€™t use, changes in library popularity over time, what build tools people are using, the divide between JavaScript and TypeScript usage, and much moreÂ besides.

Devographics

How JavaScript is Finally Improving the Module Experience â€” Multiple long-term proposals collectively known as â€œmodule harmonyâ€ will complete the features lost as developers move away fromÂ CommonJS.

Mary Branscombe / The New Stack

Simplify Your Data Collection with a Fully Integrated Form Management Platform â€” SurveyJS is an open-source JavaScript library suite for secure form creation and data collection in your app. Build JSON-driven surveys/forms quickly, without manual coding. Integrate with any backend system, gather and store responses while retaining full control over yourÂ data.

SurveyJS sponsor

How React 19 (Almost) Made the Internet Slower â€” Even changes that are planned in advance can have big effects on the developer experience if people arenâ€™t aware of them. A change to Suspense in React 19 led to much confusion and surprise, but the story has a happy ending with the React team ready to listen to end users moreÂ closely.

Henrique Yuji

IN BRIEF:

  • Evan You, the creator of Vue.js, recently gave â–¶ï¸Â a talk on 10 years of Vue, covering both its past andÂ future.

  • Over on Twitter/X, Daniel Lemire showed off a situation where Bun is much faster than Node.js, even when both are using the same underlying library, due to the complexities the V8 engineÂ introduces.

  • ğŸµ Did you know TC39 now has its own pop group and aÂ song?

RELEASES:

  • htmx 2.0 â€“ The popular 'access lots of JS and Web API features via special HTML attributes' library gets a new major version mainly to remove deprecations and drop IEÂ support.

  • Electron 31 â€“ The cross-platform desktop app framework steps up to Chromium 126, Node 20.14, and V8Â 12.6.

  • Relay 17 â€“ Facebook's declaritive GraphQL client forÂ React.

  • ESLint 9.5, Serverless Framework v4, pnpm 9.4

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.

Render sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

â–¶Â Â 3D in TypeScript with Raycasting â€” Raycasting is a somewhat old fashioned technique to render 3D environments (you may have seen it in 1992â€™s Wolfenstein 3D) but itâ€™s easy to understand and worth implementing at leastÂ once.

Tsoding Daily

Live Types in a TypeScript Monorepo â€” Several strategies to make a TypeScript monorepo feel more â€œaliveâ€ in the sense of the propagation ofÂ changes.

Colin McDonnell

Intro to Sentry & Codecov: Live Demo â€” From pre to post-release, learn how Sentry help developers find and fix errors and slowdowns and deploy withÂ confidence.

Sentry sponsor

What Happens When a Major npm Library Goes Commercial? â€” The ua-parser-js library is commonly used to parse user agent strings and gets over 12 million downloads a month, but it has recently switched to AGPL+commercialÂ licensing.

Matteo Collina

Dual Publishing ESM and CJS Modules with tsup and 'Are the TypesÂ Wrong' â€” tsup makes it easy to bundle TypeScript libraries and 'Are the Types Wrong?' analyzes packages for issues with theirÂ types.

John Reilly

ğŸ“„ How to Use Google Sheets as a 'Database' from React Paul Scanlon

ğŸ“º How Svelte and RSCs are Changing Web Development â€“ A group discussion including Svelteâ€™s Rich Harris, Tracy Lee, Ben Lesh, and AdamÂ Rackis. This Dot Media

ğŸ“„ Mastering Date Formatting using Intl.DateTimeFormat Rafael Camargo

ğŸ“„ MobX Memoizes Components (You Don't Need React Compiler) â€“ If youâ€™re actually using MobX, thatÂ is. Mike Johnson

ğŸ“„ Refactoring a Scroll-Driven Animation from JavaScript to CSS Andrico Karoulla

ğŸ“„ UUIDv7 Implemented in 20 Languages â€“ Surprisingly short andÂ sweet. Anton Zhiyanov

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Phoenix: A macOS Window Manager You Can Script with JS â€” macOS is set to adding more window management features in Sequoia, but how about something you can script entirely with JavaScript right now? GitHubÂ repo.

Kasper Hirvikoski

JSONEditor: A Component for Viewing and Editing JSON â€” If your app needs to let users work with JSON directly, this is worth a look. It supports both text and tree views and is cross browser compatible. LiveÂ demo.

Jos de Jong

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” "Compared to our previous experiences in the security/auth space, Userfront is an order of magnitude simpler toÂ use."

Userfront sponsor

Rooster v9.6: Microsoft's Framework-Independent Rich Text Editor â€” A rich-text editor control neatly nested inside a single div element (demo). Several years old, but stillÂ maintained.

Microsoft

NLUX: A Library for Rendering Conversational AI Experiences â€” If you want to spin up a ChatGPT-style conversational experience on top of your own services or third party AI backends, this provides the pieces needed to get an interface up quickly. GitHubÂ repo.

Salmen Hichri

âš™ï¸ NodeSwift â€“ Bridges Node.js and Swift so you can write Swift code that talks to Node and viceÂ versa. Kabir Oberai

âš™ï¸ Vuesion â€“ Boilerplate for Next/Vue appÂ development. Werner-Most Ideen GmbH

âš™ï¸ Kitbag Router â€“ Type safe router forÂ Vue.js. Craig Harshbarger

QUICK RELEASES:

  • Electron Store 10.0 â€“ Simple data persistence for ElectronÂ apps.

  • React Date Picker 7.1 â€“ Simple date picker component.Â (Demo.)

  • Monads 0.7 â€“ Rust-inspired Option, Result, and Either types.

  • Plasmo 0.88 â€“ "Like Next.js for browserÂ extensions."

  • MUI X 7.7 â€“ Popular React componentÂ suite.

  • React Tag Autocomplete 7.3

ğŸ¤– QUICK NOTE

Next week, I'm attending the AI Engineer World's Fair. If you happen to be there, come and say hi!

It might be a bit late to attend in person unless you're based in SF, but you can subscribe to the AI Engineer YouTube channel to be notified when the livestreams go live next Wednesday and Thursday if you'd like to see what's goingÂ on.

â€” Peter Cooper, your editor

items.title: The biggest TypeScript release in years?
items.content:
#â€‹692 â€” June 13, 2024

Read on the Web

ğŸ“ I've recently encountered readers who've been surprised to learn this isn't our only JavaScript newsletter. We have Node Weekly and React Status too â€“ check them out if you're a Node.js or React developer, as we focus more closely on them there!Â :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper

JavaScript Weekly

TC39 Meets Again and Advances Key Proposals â€” The Ecma TC39 group that pushes forward the development of ECMA/JavaScript met again this week and moved several key proposals forward, including Deferred Import Evaluation, Error.isError(), RegExp escaping, and Promise.try.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

Announcing TypeScript 5.5 RC â€” This is shaping up to be one of TypeScriptâ€™s more significant releases, with popular dev-YouTuber Theo â–¶ï¸Â dropping a 30 minute video on what heâ€™s calling â€œthe biggest TypeScript release inÂ years.â€

Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft)

WorkOS: Enterprise-Grade Auth You Can Implement inÂ Minutes â€” Like an enterprise plan in a box: WorkOS provides flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, Audit Logs, User Management, and RBAC. It's used by some of the hottest startups including Perplexity, Vercel, & Webflow. Future-proof your auth stack withÂ WorkOS.

WorkOS sponsor

How to Compose JS Functions That Take Multiple Parameters â€” â€œFunction composition is beautiful,â€ says James, who goes on to explain, in his usually elegant way, the use of partial application, currying, composite data structures, andÂ more.

James Sinclair

IN BRIEF:

  • An industry survey has found while Rust's popularity is growing rapidly, but 'JavaScript continues to take the top spot for programmingÂ languages'.

  • The stabilization process of Deno's Standard Library has begun.

  • ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡ª NodeConf EU is back, taking place in Ireland this November.

RELEASES:

  • Nuxt 3.12 â€“ The Vue.js meta framework.

  • Bun 1.1.13 â€“ The one that isn't Node orÂ Deno.

  • Node.js v22.3.0 (Current), Ember 5.9, Inertia 1.2, Astro 4.10

State of Frontend 2024 Survey Is Out Now! Hundreds Have AlreadyÂ Joined â€” Spare a few minutes to fill in the survey and receive a free report on the future of frontendÂ development.

The Software House sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

'I Tried React Compiler Today, and Guess What..' â€” The recently unveiled React Compiler automatically memoizes things â€“ so can we ditch memo, useMemo and useCallback right away? Nadia investigates, finds the rough edges, and helps keep our feet on theÂ ground.

Nadia Makarevich

'How a Single Vulnerability Can Bring Down the JS Ecosystem' â€” A slightly alarmist headline and itâ€™s more about npm, but the issue outlined could have nonetheless posed big problems â€“ luckily, GitHub is on theÂ case.

Roni Carta (Lupin)

Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.

Render sponsor

Generating ZIP Files with JavaScript â€” JSZip makes it easy to dynamically create an archive for users toÂ download.

Josh Martin

Using Node.js's Test Runner: The Official Guide â€” A new guide on the official Node site covering the fundamentals of using Nodeâ€™s new test runner functionality, along with snapshot tests (supported by NodeÂ 22.3).

Jacob Smith

ğŸ“„ Using the Page Visibility API â€“ Set up event listeners to do things when page visiblityÂ changes. Brian Smith

ğŸ“„ Getting Started with Directus and Preact â€“ Directus is a headless CMS built on top of Node andÂ Vue. Jay Bharadia

ğŸ“„ Powering Angular with Rust via WebAssembly â€“ How you could start using Rust in your AngularÂ app. Evgeniy Oz

ğŸ“„ Angular Directives vs. Vue Directives Christian Nwamba

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

DGM.js: Infinite Canvas Library with Smart Shapes â€” A library for rendering and working with infinitely pannable canvases that contain â€˜smart shapesâ€™ that you can script and give various constraints and properties. GPLv3Â licensed.

Minkyu Lee

Pastel 3.0: A Framework for Building Ink Apps â€” Ink brings the power of JSX and React components to building command line apps. Pastel provides more structure on top of that in a Next.jsÂ fashion.

Vadim Demedes

Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You'reÂ welcome.

FusionAuth sponsor

uuid v10: Generate RFC-Compliant UUIDs â€” Covers all major UUID standards. Works across all major browsers and Node 18+. v10.0 adds support for more types of RFC9562Â UUIDs (namely v6, v7 and v8).

Robert Kieffer and contributors

JsonTree.js: Customizable Tree Views for JSON Data â€” No dependencies, lots of customizations, and itâ€™s easy to theme the trees using CSS variables. Try out some examples on the docsÂ site.

William Troup

Turf.js 7.0: Geospatial Engine for Browsers and Node â€” A collection of modules for doing spatial analysis, working with GeoJSON data, data classification, and more. GitHubÂ repo.

Morgan Herlocker

Parvus 2.6: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies â€” I love how it says not to use overlays on web pages but if you have to, use this! Thereâ€™s a CodePenÂ example.

Benjamin de Oostfrees

DON'T OVERLOOK THESE:

âš™ï¸ Dukpy â€“ A simple JavaScript interpreter forÂ Python. Alessandro Molina

âš™ï¸ ngx-sonner â€“ An opinionated toast notifications component for Angular, inspired by the ReactÂ equivalent. Clara Castillo

âš™ï¸ River.ts â€“ A composable, type-safe Server-Sent Events (SSE) interface. Matthias Tellen

âš™ï¸ JSVectorMap â€“ Render interactive maps for visualizations. Mustafa Omar

QUICK RELEASES:

  • Lambda API 1.1 â€“ Zero dependency web framework for serverless JSÂ apps.

  • TS-Pattern 5.2 â€“ Pattern matching library with smart typeÂ inference.

  • ğŸ—“ï¸ React Big Calendar 1.13 â€“ GCal/Outlook-like calendarÂ component.

  • YouTube.js 10.0 â€“ An unofficial way to use YouTube's internalÂ API.

  • Starry Night 3.4 â€“ High quality GitHub-like syntaxÂ highlighting.

  • BlockNote 0.14 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor.

  • Marked 13 â€“ Fast Markdown compilerÂ /Â parser.

ğŸÂ And One for Fun

Bread Jam: Make Variables and Properties Easier to See in VS Code â€” An interesting new VS Code extension that offers 11 different ways to make variable names stand out more in your editor, with both basic colorization approaches and an interesting emoji-based prefixÂ option.

Ting Wei Jing
items.contentSnippet:
#â€‹692 â€” June 13, 2024


Read on the Web



ğŸ“ I've recently encountered readers who've been surprised to learn this isn't our only JavaScript newsletter. We have Node Weekly and React Status too â€“ check them out if you're a Node.js or React developer, as we focus more closely on them there!Â :-)
__
Your editor, Peter Cooper






    
    

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
TC39 Meets Again and Advances Key Proposals â€” The Ecma TC39 group that pushes forward the development of ECMA/JavaScript met again this week and moved several key proposals forward, including Deferred Import Evaluation, Error.isError(), RegExp escaping, and Promise.try.
Sarah Gooding (Socket) 


  
  
Announcing TypeScript 5.5 RC â€” This is shaping up to be one of TypeScriptâ€™s more significant releases, with popular dev-YouTuber Theo â–¶ï¸Â dropping a 30 minute video on what heâ€™s calling â€œthe biggest TypeScript release inÂ years.â€
Daniel Rosenwasser (Microsoft) 


  
  
WorkOS: Enterprise-Grade Auth You Can Implement inÂ Minutes â€” Like an enterprise plan in a box: WorkOS provides flexible, easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, Audit Logs, User Management, and RBAC. It's used by some of the hottest startups including Perplexity, Vercel, & Webflow. Future-proof your auth stack withÂ WorkOS.
WorkOS sponsor


  
  
How to Compose JS Functions That Take Multiple Parameters â€” â€œFunction composition is beautiful,â€ says James, who goes on to explain, in his usually elegant way, the use of partial application, currying, composite data structures, andÂ more.
James Sinclair 


IN BRIEF:
An industry survey has found while Rust's popularity is growing rapidly, but 'JavaScript continues to take the top spot for programmingÂ languages'.
The stabilization process of Deno's Standard Library has begun.
ğŸ‡®ğŸ‡ª NodeConf EU is back, taking place in Ireland this November.


RELEASES:
Nuxt 3.12 â€“ The Vue.js meta framework.
Bun 1.1.13 â€“ The one that isn't Node orÂ Deno.
Node.js v22.3.0 (Current), Ember 5.9, Inertia 1.2, Astro 4.10


  
  
State of Frontend 2024 Survey Is Out Now! Hundreds Have AlreadyÂ Joined â€” Spare a few minutes to fill in the survey and receive a free report on the future of frontendÂ development.
The Software House sponsor


ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials





  
  
'I Tried React Compiler Today, and Guess What..' â€” The recently unveiled React Compiler automatically memoizes things â€“ so can we ditch memo, useMemo and useCallback right away? Nadia investigates, finds the rough edges, and helps keep our feet on theÂ ground.
Nadia Makarevich 


  
  
'How a Single Vulnerability Can Bring Down the JS Ecosystem' â€” A slightly alarmist headline and itâ€™s more about npm, but the issue outlined could have nonetheless posed big problems â€“ luckily, GitHub is on theÂ case.
Roni Carta (Lupin) 


  
  
Your Fastest Path to Production â€” Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease â€“ from your first user to yourÂ billionth.
Render sponsor


  
  
Generating ZIP Files with JavaScript â€” JSZip makes it easy to dynamically create an archive for users toÂ download.
Josh Martin 


  
  
Using Node.js's Test Runner: The Official Guide â€” A new guide on the official Node site covering the fundamentals of using Nodeâ€™s new test runner functionality, along with snapshot tests (supported by NodeÂ 22.3).
Jacob Smith 


ğŸ“„ Using the Page Visibility API â€“ Set up event listeners to do things when page visiblityÂ changes. Brian Smith
ğŸ“„ Getting Started with Directus and Preact â€“ Directus is a headless CMS built on top of Node andÂ Vue. Jay Bharadia
ğŸ“„ Powering Angular with Rust via WebAssembly â€“ How you could start using Rust in your AngularÂ app. Evgeniy Oz
ğŸ“„ Angular Directives vs. Vue Directives  Christian Nwamba


ğŸ› Â Code & Tools




  





  
  
DGM.js: Infinite Canvas Library with Smart Shapes â€” A library for rendering and working with infinitely pannable canvases that contain â€˜smart shapesâ€™ that you can script and give various constraints and properties. GPLv3Â licensed.
Minkyu Lee 


  
  
Pastel 3.0: A Framework for Building Ink Apps â€” Ink brings the power of JSX and React components to building command line apps. Pastel provides more structure on top of that in a Next.jsÂ fashion.
Vadim Demedes 


  
  
Add Authorization, MFA, Biometrics and More to Your JavaScript App in Just Minutes â€” It's about time that somebody talked some sense about OAuth and JavaScript. So we did. You'reÂ welcome.
FusionAuth sponsor


  
  
uuid v10: Generate RFC-Compliant UUIDs â€” Covers all major UUID standards. Works across all major browsers and Node 18+. v10.0 adds support for more types of RFC9562Â UUIDs (namely v6, v7 and v8).
Robert Kieffer and contributors 


  
  
JsonTree.js: Customizable Tree Views for JSON Data â€” No dependencies, lots of customizations, and itâ€™s easy to theme the trees using CSS variables. Try out some examples on the docsÂ site.
William Troup 






  
  
Turf.js 7.0: Geospatial Engine for Browsers and Node â€” A collection of modules for doing spatial analysis, working with GeoJSON data, data classification, and more. GitHubÂ repo.
Morgan Herlocker 


  
  
Parvus 2.6: Accessible Lightbox with No Dependencies â€” I love how it says not to use overlays on web pages but if you have to, use this! Thereâ€™s a CodePenÂ example.
Benjamin de Oostfrees 





DON'T OVERLOOK THESE:
âš™ï¸ Dukpy â€“ A simple JavaScript interpreter forÂ Python. Alessandro Molina
âš™ï¸ ngx-sonner â€“ An opinionated toast notifications component for Angular, inspired by the ReactÂ equivalent. Clara Castillo
âš™ï¸ River.ts â€“ A composable, type-safe Server-Sent Events (SSE) interface. Matthias Tellen
âš™ï¸ JSVectorMap â€“ Render interactive maps for visualizations. Mustafa Omar


QUICK RELEASES:
Lambda API 1.1 â€“ Zero dependency web framework for serverless JSÂ apps.
TS-Pattern 5.2 â€“ Pattern matching library with smart typeÂ inference.
ğŸ—“ï¸ React Big Calendar 1.13 â€“ GCal/Outlook-like calendarÂ component.
YouTube.js 10.0 â€“ An unofficial way to use YouTube's internalÂ API.
Starry Night 3.4 â€“ High quality GitHub-like syntaxÂ highlighting.
BlockNote 0.14 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor.
Marked 13 â€“ Fast Markdown compilerÂ /Â parser.


ğŸÂ And One for Fun




  








  
  
Bread Jam: Make Variables and Properties Easier to See in VS Code â€” An interesting new VS Code extension that offers 11 different ways to make variable names stand out more in your editor, with both basic colorization approaches and an interesting emoji-based prefixÂ option.
Ting Wei Jing

items.title: The appealing simplicity of htmx
items.content:
#â€‹691 â€” June 6, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Promises from the Ground Up â€” Josh notes that in order to truly understand promises, a fundamental part of modern JS development, we need â€œa surprisingly deep understanding of how JavaScript works and what its limitations areâ€. Luckily, this tutorial covers all the critical context youÂ need.

Josh W Comeau

ğŸ’¡ If you're a bit more advanced, you might enjoy Alex MacArthur's look at controlling promises using Promise.withResolvers().

A Powerful JavaScript Reporting Tool Built for theÂ Web â€” ActiveReportsJS is the premier JavaScript reporting tool designed for advanced data visualizations in web applications. With many different advanced report builders and viewers, insights can be seamlessly shared with your entire userÂ base.

ActiveReportsJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

htmx: Simplicity in an Age of Complicated Solutions â€” htmx provides access to numerous dynamic features, like Ajax requests and page updates, by way of HTML attributes, and has been increasing in popularity recently. Erik looks at why its simplicity is particularlyÂ appealing.

Erik Heemskerk

ğŸ“º YouTuber DevelopedByEd has a neat â–¶ï¸ 15 minute Go + htmx quickstart screencast targeting JavaScript developers keen to explore newÂ approaches.

IN BRIEF:

  • âš™ï¸ ESLint has unveiled a new ESLint configuration migrator to help bring your config files up toÂ speed.

  • Astro's Starlight documentation site framework has turned one year old â€“ v1.0 is due later thisÂ year.

  • The Val Town bite-size JavaScript deployment platform is really taking off. They've added a page of trending Vals to show off what people areÂ upÂ to.

  • WebAssemblyâ€™s JavaScript Promise Integration (JSPI) API has a new API in ChromeÂ 126+.

RELEASES:

  • Turborepo 2.0 â€“ The high-performance buildÂ system.

  • ESLint 9.4 â€“ Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

  • ğŸ¦– Docusaurus 3.4 â€“ The fantastic site / docs site framework.

  • Prettier 3.3, Biome 1.8, Ember.js 5.9, pnpm 9.2

Revolutionizing UI Development with Chromatic and StackBlitz â€” In our upcoming live stream, we'll be speaking with the Chromatic team about actionable strategies to improve your design systemÂ workflow.

StackBlitz sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Data Fetching Patterns in Single-Page Applications â€” With a level of depth youâ€™d expect from a Martin Fowler production, Atlassianâ€™s Juntao Qiu walks through five different patterns to consider when fetching remote data, using a realistic scenario to show themÂ off.

Juntao Qiu and Martin Fowler

A Brisk VS Code Extension Development Speedrun â€” Literally a brisk tutorial, but Brisk is also the name of a CI tool the extension in question is being developedÂ for.

Sean Reilly

Tracing: Frontend Issues with Backend Solutions â€” Join us live to learn how to identify the issues causing poor Core Web Vitals and trace them through yourÂ stack.

Sentry sponsor

Full Stack Web Push API Guide â€” A complete implementation of push notifications in a Remix app. â€œIf you follow the walk through to the end, youâ€™ll have working pushÂ notifications.â€

Boaz Sender

ğŸ“„ Node Leaking Memory? setTimeout Could be the Reason Armin Ronacher

ğŸ“„ Write Your First Chrome Extension: A Guide Lizzie Paris

ğŸ“„ Goodbye Netlify, Hello Cloudflare â€“ When the bandwidth charges start toÂ sting.. Harrison Broadbent

ğŸ“º Effortless Vue.js Forms CDRUC

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Motion Canvas: Create Dynamic Canvas-Rendered Animations â€” Thereâ€™s two parts. A library where you use generator functions to procedurally define animations, and an editor that provides a real-time preview of said animations which you can see in actionÂ here.

Motion Canvas

Merge Anything 6.0: Merge Objects and Other Types Recursively â€” If youâ€™re looking for something that goes a bit deeper than Object.assign(), say.

Luca Ban

TypeScriptToLua: Write Lua with TypeScript â€” Lua is embedded in all sorts of places (games, Redis, NGINX..) so being able to write JavaScript and have it converted could open up some extra opportunities forÂ you.

TypeScriptToLua Contributors

Breakpoints and console.log is the Past, Time Travel is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Zigar: Write and Use Zig Code in Node and Electron Projects â€” Zig is a newish systems language thatâ€™s essentially a superset of C/C++. Zigar wants to make using C/C++/Zig code easier in JavaScriptÂ projects.

Chung Leong

  • Wouter 3.2 â€“ Minimalist router for React &Â Preact. You can now use regular expressions to define custom route patternsÂ too.

  • PKI.js 3.1 â€“ Pure JS library for working with public key oriented systems. Certificates, signing,Â etc.

  • Fontsource â€“ 1700+ open source fonts packaged as npmÂ packages.

  • tscircuit â€“ Design circuit boards using a React-basedÂ approach.

  • Prisma 5.15 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript.

  • melonJS 17.3 â€“ Lightweight HTML5 gameÂ engine.

ğŸ¤–Â A quick AI-side

First, a handy library:

KaTeX: The Fastest Math Typesetting Library for the Web â€” All these AI And machine learning papers and blog posts these days are crammed with mathematical notation, so how about a no dependency, TeX-based approach to rendering them? The sandbox demo page shows off how smooth itÂ is.

Emily Eisenberg and Sophie Alpert

Second, you may recall that last year (in issue 654) I mentioned a new AI engineering event being put on by two JavaScript developers called The AI Engineer Summit. It turned out to be fantastic and it's back later this month in a much larger form called The AI Engineer World's Fair (June 25-27 in SanÂ Francisco).

The speaker list is a veritable 'who's who' of the ML-leaning development scene with all the main LLM providers present too, so I've decided, at the last minute, I need to be there! If you're interested in going too, they've given us a link with 30% off all the ticket prices for you toÂ use.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
